titleInfo.title: Carbon monoxide concentrations and carboxyhemoglobin profiles from commercially available portable generators equipped with a CO hazard mitigation system

name.namePart: National Institute of Standards and Technology (U.S.)

originInfo.publisher: U.S. Dept. of Commerce, National Institute of Standards and Technology ;

mods.abstract: The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) is focused on addressing the hazard of acute carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning of consumers from portable generators that can result in serious, long term health effects or death in exposed individuals. Under an interagency agreement with CPSC (CPSC-I-17-0023), the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) conducted a series of tests on four commercially available portable generators advertised as certified to one of two voluntary standards requiring CO hazard mitigation systems for portable generators. These tests characterized the indoor CO concentrations and the associated calculated carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) profiles on simulated occupants when the generators were operated in or near a test house under various operational and environmental conditions. This report presents the measured CO data and calculated COHb levels from those tests. In addition, model validation tests and simulations were performed for 2 Cases (3 tests each) to supplement those already reported in NIST Technical Note 2049.
mods.note: Stephen M. Zimmerman; Steven J. Emmerich; Matthew J. Brookman.
Title from PDF title page (viewed January 4, 2023).
Approved by the NIST Editorial Review Board on 2022-01-28
Mode of access: World Wide Web.
Systems requirements: Adobe Acrobat PDF reader.
